comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Good morning Beachcomber! The Sailors Home is an interesting one, it looks completely different today. Re the State Records NSW image, I wonder if the building with 'SOUDAN' written on it relates to the conflict which was 1885? This 1886 Trove article mentions a 'Soudan Hotel', lower George St: bit.ly/QCyvHU
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Brilliant information about the Soudan Hotel, which seems to have been a favourite place for Coroner's inquiries It doesn't rate a mention in Trove after 1888, probably due to a name change. Yes, the Sailors Home had a facelift in the 1920s on the George Street side; nearer the quay it is still recognisable. The building which fascinates me is the Mariners Church beyond, which has been endlessly 'improved' for 150 years - www.environment.nsw.gov.au/heritageapp/visit/ViewAttracti...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Haha yes - the Soudan Hotel seems to have been well known to the Coroner. I have never really noticed the Mariner's Church before, "From 1856 to 1859, the Mariners’ Church was built at the site by the Bethel Seaman’s Union. Founded in England and later established in Sydney, the 
Union was born from the widespread evangelical religious revival of the early 
19th century, which included missionary activity among seaman... During levelling of the site, the stonemasons union advised that they would 
reduce their working hours per day from twelve to eight. This was agreed to 
by the Bethel Union Trustees, making the site the first in the world to employ 
workers on an eight-hour day basis." bit.ly/T9jHhN

The early stages of a very strong Seamen's Union movement in Australia!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Indeed! The building is steeped in maritime history. I had a squizz inside when they were last renovating a couple of years ago - all dust and rubble - I think it is now a restaurant and nightclub (not sure). Before all the additions it looked like a Greek temple - 'Mariners Church' [1860] Charles Pickering, SLNSW

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: 1839 watercolour of this view by Frederick Garling - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=421837#

comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Yes, we are so used to wharves and buildings at Circular Quay. Here are a few excellent zoomable and linkable maps which show Sydney Cove much earlier - In 1802 with a 1873 red overlay - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-rm1274-sd&rgn=... In 1822 - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-f107-sd&rgn=0.... In 1837 - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-t1551-sd&rgn=0... And in 1895 the nearest date to this photo - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] They are really quite beautiful, thanks for those links beachcomber.
